--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:

> I=
 read this post on p-values that you included a link to. It doesn't say tha=
t p-values are utterly uninformative, but it does point out a lot of proble=
ms with them. 

"Utterly informative" was an exaggeration on my part, I'll =
admit. :-)

> I do not believe in a magical threshold (e.g. p=3D0.5), so I =
escape most of the criticism of this article. But I do think p-values are i=
mportant. I agree that effect size should also be important=85.but I was un=
der the impression that both are important for different reasons (one does =
not replace the other because they serve different purposes). This article =
agrees, saying you need both, since effect sizes don't focus on whether the=
 effect is true "in the world"; instead, effect sizes just describe the siz=
e of the effect in the sampe: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Effect_size
> 
>=
 Do you disagree?
> 
> Finally, most (all?) papers do report effect sizes: =
they report the mean/median +/- variance/std/stderr for treatment A vs. B, =
as well as a p-value. The effect size is the difference in the averages of =
A & B, no? The problem is that not all papers (in our field, especially) re=
port the p-value in addition, which I (and wikipedia) think they should. 
>=
 
> I'd be interested to hear why you think p-values are meaningless, and w=
hat you would propose instead to ascertain whether the sample reflects the =
true distribution. 

p-values can be replaced by constructing a 95% confide=
nce interval around the effect size (or 99%, or whatever confidence thresho=
ld we prefer) and seeing if the confidence interval overlaps with 0.0. If i=
t overlaps, it is not a significant effect; if it does not overlap, then we=
 can claim that there is a significant effect in the treatment.

Alternativ=
ely, if you don't like just showing effect size (or it is inappropriate for=
 what you're plotting), you can construct the 95% confidence interval aroun=
d treatment A and treatment B's measurements. If they overlap at all, there=
 is no significant difference; if they do not overlap at all, then there is=
 a significant difference.

This is why I always plot means and 95% confide=
nce intervals in my manuscripts so it is visually straightforward to compar=
e treatments.


> PS. The most worrisome section of this post for me is thi=
s: 
> 
> "But now suppose we've learned our lesson: and so, chastened, we a=
bandon our arbitrary threshold a value and look instead at the exact p valu=
e associated with our predictor variable, as many writers have advocated. A=
nd let's supposed that it is impressively low, say p =3D 0.00073. We conclu=
de, correctly, that if the null hypothesis were true (which we never really=
 believed in the first place) then the data we actually obtained in our sam=
ple would have been pretty unlikely. So, following standard practice, we co=
nclude that the probability that the null hypothesis is true is only 0.0007=
3. Right? Wrong. We have confused the probability of the data if you are gi=
ven the hypothesis,  P(Data|H0), which is p, with its inverse probability P=
(H0|Data), the probability of the hypothesis if you are given the data, whi=
ch is something else entirely. Ironically, we can compute the inverse proba=
bility from the original probability =96 but only if we adopt a Bayesian ap=
proach that allows for "subjective" probabilities. That approach says that =
you begin the study of some prior belief (expressed as a probability) in a =
given hypothesis, and adjust that in light of your new data."
>

that I do tend to do this: "following standard practice, we conclude that t=
he probability that the null hypothesis is true is only 0.00073." 
>

 be happy to switch to the Bayesian approach, though I don't know much abou=
t it yet. Do you know of a nice, short, introduction to this paradigm?

I'l=
